question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Creative Cartography course created a highly engaging and supportive learning environment that encouraged both critical thinking and creative exploration. Professor Triplett structured the course in a way that balanced technical skill-building in map-making with deep conceptual inquiry into spatial narratives and visual storytelling. I particularly appreciated the open-ended nature of the assignments, which allowed me to align course projects with my dissertation interests on historical land use and environmental change.  The class discussions and weekly readings provided a strong theoretical foundation that challenged me to think more deeply about what maps represent—and what they omit. The feedback sessions, especially peer critiques and one-on-one check-ins, were extremely valuable for refining both the design and intent behind my maps.One of the most effective components I would recommend keeping is the scaffolded structure of the final project. It was incredibly helpful to break the process into stages (proposal, moodboard, draft, etc.), which made the final creative deliverable feel achievable and purposeful. I also found the integration of both analog and digital cartographic techniques to be pedagogically rich, and I’d encourage maintaining that blend in future iterations of the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved learning a little about cartography through our course readings outside of the lab work. The class felt very well - rounded because I was not only engaging with readings and discussions, but also with the mapping program itself. I also appreciate that I was encouraged to think creatively and given plenty of freedom to design my project.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Not only did the instructor teach all the basic skills of navigating the software, he made sure that he would be happy to help you learn any additional skills that might be useful for the topic you chose. The way he can teach the material tailored to each student's level, interest, and type of project was wonderful, and though it was a large class, it still had a depth of one-on-one teaching.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I wish I could take the same course again because I feel like it would be just as stimulating the second time around.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Pro Triplett was consistently engaged and excited to share his knowledge with us, but for us to feel as though our reflections on new material helped grow the subject matter discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because it invited us to rethink maps not just as tools for representation, but as cultural, political, and artistic artifacts. The integration of critical theory with hands-on design work created a unique space to experiment and question—something I haven’t experienced in other courses. The encouragement to situate our own identities and research within our mapping projects made the work personally meaningful and conceptually rich.What made the course especially engaging was the freedom to pursue a self-directed final project. It pushed me to synthesize spatial analysis, historical research, and visual storytelling in new ways. I was able to explore how cartography can represent liminal spaces and historical erasure—central themes in my dissertation.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Whether you decide that mapping is your thing or not, this class will help you refine your research questions and data visualization. The class content, energy, and instruction are great and highly recommended!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're even remotely interested in maps, visual storytelling, or thinking critically about how space and place are represented, take this course. Creative Cartography is unlike any other class—it's where theory meets art, and where personal narrative meets spatial analysis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The self-directed structure of the class let us explore our own interests in-depth by sticking with one project throughout the semester. I liked that we weren’t boxed into one kind of interface or topic & our presentations let each of us dive into interfaces that we were genuinely curious about. The presentation-based format also made it easy to learn from each other and see a wide range. I liked the flexible structure & think it encouraged creativity. We also kept our own "Book of Notice" throughout the semester & it was up to us what we put/how often we updated; this was also a nice way to be creative & see/be inspired by our moodboards.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked that we got to define our own direction and explore ideas that genuinely interested us. To make the class even more intellectually stimulating, it could be helpful to look at a broader range of real-world experimental interfaces together as a class. While we were encouraged to explore, some of the presentations—both mine and others—started to feel a bit repetitive and leaned heavily toward apps and consumer products. It would’ve been exciting to get more exposure to how different interface concepts are being applied in fields like art, tech, and research. Professor Seaman was also knowledgeable & knew a lot of different interfaces/works/research relevant to our presentation/project topics off the top of his head; it might have been more engaging to learn directly from some examples/insights alongside student presentations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I have learned:
1. In terms of editing, I have been exposed to the editing of many experimental video works. This is very different from the montage editing and narrative editing that I used to be familiar with.
2. Static image and sound design, this is a new attempt for me, experimental creation of sound.
3. Professor Lion inspired me to try creating and editing experimental videos using my own body as a medium.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

A conscious reflection on the purposefulness that editing poses for film theory. 
A reliable praxis for reading and comprehending dense visual material. 
An open ended understanding of peer critique.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The diversity of the assignments and getting feedback on them throughout the semester also helped with tracking improvement and exploring different ways of editing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was structured in a way that had students present on the readings each week. This allowed students to gain experience synthesizing information and presenting it to a big group, but there were also some readings or concepts that I feel should have been introduced by the professor, instead (i.e. the major topics or themes that would underscore the entire semester). question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed several valuable ways of thinking and analysis. First, I was introduced to foundational game theories that helped me understand how systems of rules, play, and interaction can be used to critique and reimagine social dynamics. Second, I strengthened my analytical mindset by learning to draw connections between diverse readings, case studies, and media, bringing together theory and practice in meaningful ways during discussion. Finally, I began to see technology not just as a tool but as a medium that shapes how we understand identity and selfhood, especially through immersive experiences like games, virtual realities, and interactive media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Best practices for designing and conducting interviews and surveys for user studies.
2. Ideas specific to my final project topic - User perceptions of security and privacy issues when using LLMs.
3. Security and privacy considerations that are specific to certain populations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The importance of conducting user perspective studies and seeking public opinions regarding privacy and security topics, becoming more aware of and better able to recognize specific risks sub populations are particularly vulnerable to in regards to privacy and security matters that the general public may not worry about, and how to go about and begin one's own reiterative coding process for an explorative qualitative research study.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned a lot about the state-of-the-art research in privacy and security. 
The variety of the topics also helped me broaden my knowledge of different applications in the context of privacy and security. 
I learned how to properly design a user study and what types of data analysis are needed for each type of study.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about threat modeling, privacy paradox, and different types of security attacks.

response_text: How to design a survey.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Conducting Surveys: I learned to design and distribute surveys using the Qualtrics platform.
2. Literature Review: I gained skills in reading and identifying the latest papers in the field.
3. Conducting Ethical Research: We applied for IRB approval, and I learned how to conduct ethics reviews.

response_text: We worked on a group project through the semester, conducting our own UX research to identify a design problem and propose solutions. I enjoyed the hands-on collaborative nature of this and liked that we had a "speed-dating" class to identify who would be a good fit to work with. I like looking at case studies, such as examples of company rebrands/branding (Buc-ee's, Walmart rebrand, M&Ms mascots, etc.); those were informative and it was interesting to discuss what was done right/wrong. I also really liked the guest speakers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The specifics of design thinking to execute a concept (e.g. mapping out exactly what a user is doing and what kind of output or feedback they should be getting in return)
2. Learning to see the logic of design as a whole system (like how an input gives an output, and how that links back to the overall functionality). We did a lot of sketching and diagramming to outline these relationships
3. Imagining more experimental/unique interfaces & thinking of unusual/new ways people can interact with a computer, such as touch, sound, motion, even things like environmental changes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The self-directed structure of the class let us explore our own interests in-depth by sticking with one project throughout the semester. I liked that we weren’t boxed into one kind of interface or topic & our presentations let each of us dive into interfaces that we were genuinely curious about. The presentation-based format also made it easy to learn from each other and see a wide range. I liked the flexible structure & think it encouraged creativity. We also kept our own "Book of Notice" throughout the semester & it was up to us what we put/how often we updated; this was also a nice way to be creative & see/be inspired by our moodboards.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked that we got to define our own direction and explore ideas that genuinely interested us. To make the class even more intellectually stimulating, it could be helpful to look at a broader range of real-world experimental interfaces together as a class. While we were encouraged to explore, some of the presentations—both mine and others—started to feel a bit repetitive and leaned heavily toward apps and consumer products. It would’ve been exciting to get more exposure to how different interface concepts are being applied in fields like art, tech, and research. Professor Seaman was also knowledgeable & knew a lot of different interfaces/works/research relevant to our presentation/project topics off the top of his head; it might have been more engaging to learn directly from some examples/insights alongside student presentations.

response_text: This class was not intellectually stimulating. I would propose that students work towards making an actual website at the end of the project instead of making a slideshow presentation as we did not implement any skills of interface design. This class is more accurately described as a discussion class since there was a lack of knowledge being applied. Each week’s class was the same with presentations taking the entire period, so I would get rid of these a commit to having an open discussion about specific principles and techniques each class to add direction.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this media theory course, I gained a deep understanding of media's evolution, from foundational debates about writing and mediation to contemporary digital culture. The course equipped me with critical frameworks to analyze how different media forms - from print to digital platforms - shape human experience and social relationships. Key theoretical concepts like technological determinism, cultural techniques, and media archaeology enhanced my ability to examine the complex interplay between media, technology, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class has given me a whole new understanding of the concept of media. Because before I chose this major, I knew almost nothing about media. In this class, I learned a lot about the concept of media and the historical process of media. In particular, I am deeply impressed by McLuhan's theory. He taught me that media can influence our perception and shape our society. And I also realized commodification and entertainment, it makes me know that we need to keep our own judgment in the market to find the real value

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed a more nuanced and open mindset toward failure as a necessary and even valuable part of growth both personally and professionally. Three specific things I learned were:
 I learned how to reinterpret failure not as a setback, but as a meaningful part of the creative and innovation process. The course helped me understand that failure is often where the most valuable insights come from.
 I developed skills in personal reflection through writing and discussion which allowed me to better process my experiences and view them through emotional and intellectual lenses.
 The course encouraged me to step outside of my comfort zone and take creative and intellectual risks without fear of being "wrong." That shift in thinking was incredibly freeing and helped me grow more confident in uncertain situations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of foundational information about the importance of feminism in both real life and the digital space, the prevalence of sexism in Silicon Valley, and various online spaces perpetuating sexist narratives. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned and became extremely proficient in Adobe Premire.
I also was able to synthesize social theory with contemporary tech issues
I developed a way of thinking of seeing technology not as neutral, but shaped by and reinforcing power structures (race, gender, class, ability).

I lastly learned how to use interfaces such as Premier Pro to become more comfortable with video making and editing, which will be very helpful in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Henschel and Gelfand were always available for extra help with our video projects and writing. Additionally, they both made sure our external readings and documentary studies were relevant to the course and facilitated intellectually stimulating discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The one minute videos on Premiere Pro, the final project, and the forum posts all encouraged my engagement with the course. I would keep the one minute videos and the final project. I also loved group work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this class was dynamic, inclusive, and deeply engaging. Professors Gelfand and Henschel cultivated a space where theory and practice met in meaningful ways. The combination of seminar-style discussions, creative media assignments (One Minute videos, Zine workshop), and collaborative final projects allowed for a multifaceted learning experience that accommodated a wide range of learning styles.For future years, I would strongly recommend keeping the combination of theory-based readings, digital production, and the reflective essay as core pillars of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

It allowed for the sharing of opinions, and ideas on the readings/videos that we were assigned and also allowed for conversations relating to more personal application experiences.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned about user research methods in human centered computing. More specifically, about qualitative and quantitative research methods, as well as other relevant topics (accessibility, privacy/security, etc.) in such research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: You learn all about HCI, how to conduct your own studies, and about the importance of preventing biases in your research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different research methods and how to pick which ones are best for specific research goals. This included weighing the limitations and strengths of these methods and deciding what factors were most important. I learned how to develop questions to limit bias while still collecting the necessary information. I also learned a lot about the usability of different products - how to test the usability and also how to design more usable products.

Based on my experience in other seminars, dividing class time more evenly—half instructor-led and half student-led—has proven to be a more effective and enriching structure. This approach provides a stronger foundation for discussion and fosters a more consistent and engaging learning experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed several valuable ways of thinking and analysis. First, I was introduced to foundational game theories that helped me understand how systems of rules, play, and interaction can be used to critique and reimagine social dynamics. Second, I strengthened my analytical mindset by learning to draw connections between diverse readings, case studies, and media, bringing together theory and practice in meaningful ways during discussion. Finally, I began to see technology not just as a tool but as a medium that shapes how we understand identity and selfhood, especially through immersive experiences like games, virtual realities, and interactive media.

response_text: The Creative Cartography course created a highly engaging and supportive learning environment that encouraged both critical thinking and creative exploration. Professor Triplett structured the course in a way that balanced technical skill-building in map-making with deep conceptual inquiry into spatial narratives and visual storytelling. I particularly appreciated the open-ended nature of the assignments, which allowed me to align course projects with my dissertation interests on historical land use and environmental change.  The class discussions and weekly readings provided a strong theoretical foundation that challenged me to think more deeply about what maps represent—and what they omit. The feedback sessions, especially peer critiques and one-on-one check-ins, were extremely valuable for refining both the design and intent behind my maps.One of the most effective components I would recommend keeping is the scaffolded structure of the final project. It was incredibly helpful to break the process into stages (proposal, moodboard, draft, etc.), which made the final creative deliverable feel achievable and purposeful. I also found the integration of both analog and digital cartographic techniques to be pedagogically rich, and I’d encourage maintaining that blend in future iterations of the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved learning a little about cartography through our course readings outside of the lab work. The class felt very well - rounded because I was not only engaging with readings and discussions, but also with the mapping program itself. I also appreciate that I was encouraged to think creatively and given plenty of freedom to design my project.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Not only did the instructor teach all the basic skills of navigating the software, he made sure that he would be happy to help you learn any additional skills that might be useful for the topic you chose. The way he can teach the material tailored to each student's level, interest, and type of project was wonderful, and though it was a large class, it still had a depth of one-on-one teaching.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I wish I could take the same course again because I feel like it would be just as stimulating the second time around.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because it invited us to rethink maps not just as tools for representation, but as cultural, political, and artistic artifacts. The integration of critical theory with hands-on design work created a unique space to experiment and question—something I haven’t experienced in other courses. The encouragement to situate our own identities and research within our mapping projects made the work personally meaningful and conceptually rich.What made the course especially engaging was the freedom to pursue a self-directed final project. It pushed me to synthesize spatial analysis, historical research, and visual storytelling in new ways. I was able to explore how cartography can represent liminal spaces and historical erasure—central themes in my dissertation.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Whether you decide that mapping is your thing or not, this class will help you refine your research questions and data visualization. The class content, energy, and instruction are great and highly recommended!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed a more nuanced and open mindset toward failure as a necessary and even valuable part of growth both personally and professionally. Three specific things I learned were:
 I learned how to reinterpret failure not as a setback, but as a meaningful part of the creative and innovation process. The course helped me understand that failure is often where the most valuable insights come from.
 I developed skills in personal reflection through writing and discussion which allowed me to better process my experiences and view them through emotional and intellectual lenses.
 The course encouraged me to step outside of my comfort zone and take creative and intellectual risks without fear of being "wrong." That shift in thinking was incredibly freeing and helped me grow more confident in uncertain situations.

response_text: This course covers theoretical frameworks that inform ethical technologies (via education, surveillance, punishment, man & machine, etc.). We also considered open source practices and applied a design process to a project that we refined through extensive interview feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this media theory course, I gained a deep understanding of media's evolution, from foundational debates about writing and mediation to contemporary digital culture. The course equipped me with critical frameworks to analyze how different media forms - from print to digital platforms - shape human experience and social relationships. Key theoretical concepts like technological determinism, cultural techniques, and media archaeology enhanced my ability to examine the complex interplay between media, technology, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a new perspective on what the "media" term media can mean, gained new frameworks to understanding how society and media interact, and gained meaningful insight into how I personally interact with media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class has given me a whole new understanding of the concept of media. Because before I chose this major, I knew almost nothing about media. In this class, I learned a lot about the concept of media and the historical process of media. In particular, I am deeply impressed by McLuhan's theory. He taught me that media can influence our perception and shape our society. And I also realized commodification and entertainment, it makes me know that we need to keep our own judgment in the market to find the real value

response_text: I learned about a handful of theories and valuable insights surrounding media theory. I learned about the influence media has on our lives and how the medium affects our interpretation of the world. I learned about the media archeology and the value of evaluating how medias function fundamentally, amongst other things.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class readings were stimulating. The in person discussions were not stimulating and felt serving to the two students familiar with the material and the professor only. I also appreciated the feedback on the project proposals and found it very helpful to hear the professors response to our thoughts. That kind of engagement with our object lessons would have been beneficial early on to make sure our thinking was on the right track.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
-The Second Nature experience and review was a highlight of the semester for me. Having an outside of class activity to apply our knowledge to was very useful and fun. It could be nice to do something like that all together as a class. 
-The object lessons were stimulating at the beginning of the semester and then became a bit redundant. If there was some sort of a shift in direction with the object lessons about halfway through the semester, it could make students more engaged with them. This could be suggesting a theme to pull an object from, or connecting readings to an object that was already posted about, etc.
-Having explicit space to discuss object lessons in class would have been helpful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were excellent. Sometimes there were so many that it was hard to focus and do a deep dive into one, but I am glad to have read all of them.
